newsitem.title: USA: Deal reached on U.S. balanced budget, source says.
newsitem.headline: Deal reached on U.S. balanced budget, source says.

text.p: The White House and congressional Republican leaders on Friday reached agreement on a plan to balance the U.S. federal budget by 2002, a senior administration official said.
"We have a deal, now comes the hard part -- selling it to Congress," said a senior official who accompanied President Bill Clinton on a trip to Baltimore.

In Washington, one of the chief Republican negotiators, Sen. Pete Domenici of New Mexico, said, "I'm very happy with the agreement." Reporters were summoned to a news conference in the ornate Capital rotunda, where a sign reading "America Wins" was briefly hung in front of the speaker's podium before an aide removed it.

A deal would mark a stunning breakthrough on an issue that has snarled Washington politics for years, and one that would enable both Democrat Clinton and Republican congressional leaders to claim victory as solvers of one of America's most intractable problems.

It was understood the deal emerging from intense White House-Congress negotiations would include a net tax cut of about $85 billion over five years, a concession to the Republicans in the plan whose aim was to reduce the U.S. federal deficit to zero in five years.
